channel.title: World News Today, Trending World News, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India
channel.description: World News Today: Read the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Today, Trending World News, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: Sanjay Bhandari alleges he will face violence and extortion in Tihar Jail
item.description: Sanjay Bhandari, a defense middleman, is fighting extradition to India on charges of tax evasion and money laundering. His lawyers argue that he faces potential violence and extortion in Tihar Jail, citing overcrowding and past incidents. They also claim he would be denied a fair trial and bail. The Indian government contends that Tihar's conditions are acceptable.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Canton

item.title: Pak SC conditionally allows army to announce military trial verdicts of pro-Imran protesters
item.description: Pakistan's Supreme Court conditionally allowed military courts to deliver verdicts for 85 civilians involved in the May 9 riots. These verdicts remain subject to the court's final decision on the constitutionality of military trials for civilians. The trials stem from protests following Imran Khan's arrest, with concerns raised by human rights organizations about due process.
item.dc:creator: Omer Farooq Khan

item.title: ‘Cramer Curse’: Internet goes wild as Trump trolls Jim Cramer on live TV
item.description: During a live CNBC interview after ringing the NYSE opening bell, President-elect Trump playfully teased Jim Cramer about his market prediction track record. Trump's jab, referencing the "Cramer Curse," ignited social media with humorous reactions and memes, highlighting Cramer's often-inaccurate calls.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: AOC justifies 'lack of sympathy' for Brian Thompson: 'Denied claims are an act of violence'
item.description: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez addressed the murder of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, stating that while violence isn't justified, Americans' frustration with the healthcare system fuels such reactions. "​I think for anyone who is confused or shocked or appalled, they need to understand that people interpret and feel and experience denied claims as an act of violence against them," AOC said.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Nancy Pelosi rushed to hospital after injury during foreign trip
item.description: ​Pelosi, 84, was in Europe to mark the 80th anniversary of the Battle of the Bulge in World War II. Her spokesman, Ian Krager, said in a statement that she is “currently receiving excellent treatment from doctors and medical professionals” and is unable to attend the remainder of events on her trip.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Is RFK Jr trying to scrap the polio vaccine? Here's the truth
item.description: ​Though the petitions have no direct link with Kennedy, the NYT report said that Kennedy's close partnership with Siri suggests that vaccine policy will be under sharp scrutiny. Siri has been there with Kennedy as he interviewed candidates for his department and the candidates have been asked about vaccines. The NYT report said Siri asserted that all his petitions were filed on behalf of different clients and RFK Jr had nothing to do with those.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Trump advisers reported plan to ease banking oversight may not get required support
item.description: Donald Trump's team explored downsizing banking regulators. Wall Street remained unconcerned, citing political roadblocks. The potential elimination of the FDIC was discussed. This raised concerns about financial stability. Experts highlighted the FDIC's crucial role in bank resolutions. US bank stocks dipped marginally. The Senate Banking Committee will likely influence regulatory changes.

item.title: JD Vance invites Daniel Penny to Army-Navy game after subway trial acquittal
item.description: Marine veteran Daniel Penny, recently acquitted in the chokehold death of Jordan Neely, will attend the Army-Navy football game as a guest of Vice President-elect JD Vance. Vance praised Penny's actions and expressed gratitude for his acceptance of the invitation, extending the invitation from President-elect Trump's suite.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Far too early to lift US sanctions on Syria, says US
item.description: US senators from both parties agree it's premature to lift sanctions on Syria despite Assad's ousting. Concerns remain about the new ruling power, Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), a former al Qaeda affiliate. While some advocate for easing sanctions to aid reconstruction, others prioritize ensuring human rights and stability before any policy changes.

item.title: Luigi Mangione's raised chin shows he's arrogant: Expert decodes body language
item.description: Body language expert Susan Constantine analyzed Luigi Mangione's demeanor, noting a shift from charismatic charm to rigid fear. Mangione's raised chin and arrogant posture suggest pride, while his post-arrest frown contrasts with earlier smiles. Constantine suggests Mangione, the suspect in the Brian Thompson murder case, compartmentalizes, displaying different personalities in various situations.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Former CIA director compares Trump to Hitler. JD Vance teaches him a lesson
item.description: Former CIA Director Michael Hayden compared Trump's Time Person of the Year selection to Hitler's. VP-elect JD Vance defended Trump, criticizing "career bureaucrats" and highlighting past recipients like Obama and Clinton. Vance's defense marks a shift from his earlier criticism of Trump.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: ‘Thankfully, it wasn’t a heart attack...’: How Adam Burgoyne’s death exposed Canada’s broken healthcare system
item.description: Adam’s passing was caused by an aneurysm, a localized weakening of an artery​ wall that can lead to life-threatening internal bleeding if it ruptures. Aneurysms often develop without symptoms and are rarely diagnosed without specific screening or imaging. This silent nature makes them particularly dangerous, as individuals can go about their lives unaware of the ticking time bomb inside them.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Will Luigi Mangione face the death penalty? What New York law says
item.description: ​In New York, a first-degree murder charge applies only where the victim is a first responder like a police officer, or if the killing involves a murder-for-hire or aims to prevent a witness to a crime from testifying in court; or if the murder is an act of terrorism. In Mangione's case, a first-degree murder will be imposed if the investigation finds evidence that he had plans to kill other CEOs etc.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Trump love or Trudeau hate: Why did Jordan Peterson leave Canada?
item.description: Peterson also voiced deep concerns about Canada’s political direction under Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. He pointed to proposed legislation like Bill C-63, the so-called "Online Harms" bill, which aims to regulate online speech. Peterson argued that such laws would create a “totalitarian hell hole,” where anonymous complaints about “offensive” content could lead to severe consequences.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Did Donald Trump Jr leave Kimberly Guilfoyle to impress father? 'Someone like Melania'
item.description: Ex-Fox News host Kimberly Guilfoyle's background, dressing sense used to be derided by the Trump family, insiders said explaining why Don Jr, who always wanted to impress his father, moved on from her to Bettina Anderson, a socialite and a model, like Melania Trump. ​“Don Jr has been telling people for months that Kim is so uptight and always dresses so professionally in these kinds of dresses and high heels, and never looks relaxed or casual,” a report said.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Family, aides, and soldiers abandoned: Assad’s solo escape to Moscow
item.description: Bashar al-Assad, maintaining strict secrecy, misled aides and officials about his plans to flee Syria as his regime crumbled. He falsely assured military leaders of Russian support while orchestrating a covert departure for Moscow with his family. Left behind were his brother and cousins, who faced uncertain fates. Assad's pleas for military aid from both Russia and Iran were ultimately rejected.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Kids-for-Cash Scandal: Why Biden is underfire for pardoning Judge Michael Conahan
item.description: This decision has raised broader concerns about the messaging of clemency. While the administration aims to address systemic issues, critics warn that leniency for individuals like Conahan risks eroding public trust in the justice system. Many argue that reforms should focus on rehabilitating nonviolent offenders or those unjustly sentenced—not high-profile figures convicted of flagrant abuses of power.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Luigi Mangione and the Gray Tribe: The peculiar worldview of America’s latest heartthrob
item.description: The gray tribe is an intellectual rabbit hole so deep that even Nietzsche might’ve said, “Chill, guys.” It’s a loosely defined group of thinkers, rationalists, tech bros, and philosophy nerds who live for data-driven debates, AI discourse, and tearing apart cognitive biases like they’re the final boss in a video game. And while there’s zero evidence that Mangione’s alleged crime was linked to his intellectual leanings, his association with this subculture is fascinating.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: MAGA asks 'who is Don Lemon' after his meltdown over Trump becoming Person of the Year
item.description: ​"Is this a joke? Did we get something wrong? Did someone scam us? Are we sure about this, producers? There is a convicted felon on the cover of Time Magazine as the Person of the Year. Maybe we're being scammed. Did someone put out a fake tweet or something about this? I don’t know," Lemon continued his tirade against both Trump and the TIME.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Did Joe Biden pardon a Chinese spy who possessed child pornography? Here's the truth
item.description: President Joe Biden’s recent prisoner swap with China has sparked controversy and misinformation, with some falsely claiming he “pardoned” a Chinese national convicted of child pornography. In reality, Biden commuted the sentence of Shanlin Jin, a calculated move to secure the release of three Americans wrongfully detained in China, while imposing strict conditions on Jin’s release.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
